newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Dec 16.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian General News - Dec 16.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

The Industrial Relations Court has found employees who suffer "mental distress" or anxiety from being unfairly dismissed are entitled to compensation under the Federal dismissal laws. In the judgments handed down on Friday, the Court supported the view hat "implied terms" in employment contracts require employers to treat workers well, yet failed to allow unfairly dismissed employees to gain common law damages for "mental distress". Page 1.

Richard Court's Liberal-National Coalition was returned to power in the Western Australian election on the weekend after gaining an increased majority in the Lower House, despite a flow of protest votes to minor parties, particularly in metropolitan electorates. Page 2.

Speaking at a media conference to mark the end of the parliamentary year, Prime Minister John Howard said the Coalition's 1997 agenda will be dominated by an acceleration of micro-economic reform and a renewed focus on measures to boost employment. Howard also predicted that despite public support for a shift to a republic, Australia was unlikely to become a republic before 2000. Page 5.

In an effort to assist employers in complying with the Victorian Equal Opportunity Act, which makes it unlawful to discriminate against workers on the basis of their physical appearance, the State's Equal Opportunity Commission issued new guidelines last week stipulating that Victorian employers can set "reasonable" dress and appearance standards for employees. Page 4.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Federal Cabinet will meet this week to tackle the priorities for the first six months of next year after a busy Senate sitting left intact all but about A$1 billion of the A$36 billion in budget savings over four years. Treasurer Peter Costello said the bovernment was happy with the outcome of the Senate sittings, despite being defeated on A$400 million in welfare cuts. Page 1.

Western Australia Premier Richard Court has vowed to go ahead with a controversial plan of mandatory secret ballots before industrial action and to lobby for further reform of the Native Title Act, after his government was re-elected in the State's weeken election. Court also promised further reform but more social benefit in his government's second term. Page 1.

The one-day international cricket match between Australia and Pakistan in Adelaide yesterday finally gave Australia's cricketing public what they have been waiting for all summer - a close finish. The Pakistanis, who claim to be the world's best, defeated Australia by 12 runs after an enthusiastic performance by off-spinner Saqlain Mushtaq. Page 1.

Amendments to the Bankruptcy Act take effect from today, which will allow credit card borrowers to avoid bankruptcy by use of debt agreements - a new repayment system between financial institutions and borrowers with debts below A$50,000. The amendments to the Act are a response to increased personal bankruptcy levels across Australia, which should rise over the Christmas season. Page 3.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

The New South Wales Government's budget is slowly being pushed millions of dollars into the red as the Carr Government continues to spend money yet keeps its promise not to lift taxes or charges. The blowout includes a A$50 million increase in State Rail Authority revenue, an increase of about A$400 million in health spending, pay rises for teachers, nurses, and possibly police, the cash-back promise on the M4 and M5 motorways, and the backdown on restricting free school bus travel. Page 1.

An Australian official from the Australian consulate in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, has travelled to Saudi Arabia to assist in finding out the details of the murder of Australian nurse Yvonne Gilford, who was reportedly suffocated, stabbed and bashed with a hammer at the King Fahd Military Hospital where she had been working for six months. Page 1.

Back from a defeat at the hands of the Australian Cricket Academy, the Pakistan cricket team yesterday stole the match in the World Series limited overs competition in Adelaide against Australia by 12 runs, adding a spark to what has been an uninspiring summer of cricket. Page 1.

The Australian Consumers Association and the GeneEthics Network believe many foods are being sold in Australian supermarkets without the public knowing they contain genetically engineered soybeans containing glyphosate, a chemical that can impact on human at the cellular level, up to 200 times the allowable Australian standard. Page 3.
THE AGE

Frank Gilford, the brother of Yvonne Ruth Gilford, a 56-year-old Australian nurse murdered in a Saudi Arabian military base hospital, says his sister was an experienced nurse who was well travelled, having worked as a nurse in several countries, including spending 20 years in South Africa. Gilford described his sister as a bright and bubbly person who knew the risks involved with her posting. Page A1.

As part of a A$60 million bid to freeze unions out of education, Victorian Education Minister Phil Gude yesterday offered to grant teachers, principals and support staff two three percent pay increases in March 1997 and February 1998 on the condition the agree to bypass unions and negotiate directly with the State Government. Page A1.

The Victorian ALP suffered a major upset yesterday when the party's powerful Socialist Left faction split over what was effectively a no-confidence motion in its leadership - put behind closed doors by rebel Left MP Theo Theophanous and opponents of the fction's leader Kim Carr. The motion was narrowly defeated. Page A1.

Federal Health and Community Services Department epidemiology registrar Scott Crerar warned yesterday food poisoning outbreaks would become more frequent because many Australians had unclean habits with food and poor personal hygiene. He called for a national teaching campaign in education facilities telling people how to handle food. Page A3.
